Title.evidence: Title: Randomised Controlled Trial of Fenestrated and Branched Endovascular Aortic Repair for Aneurysm Size

Trial_Design.evidence: Randomisation was performed using a computer-generated sequence

Participants.evidence: Patients undergoing elective F/BEVAR for TAAAs and cAAAs from 2013 to 2022 in the Vascular Quality Initiative database were included

Intervention.evidence: fenestrated and branched endovascular aortic repair (F/BEVAR) for thoraco-abdominal aortic aneurysms (TAAAs) and complex abdominal aortic aneurysms (cAAAs)

Objective.evidence: This randomised controlled trial assessed outcomes following fenestrated and branched endovascular aortic repair (F/BEVAR) for thoraco-abdominal aortic aneurysms (TAAAs) and complex abdominal aortic aneurysms (cAAAs) based on aneurysm size

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was peri-operative mortality, measured within 30 days post-surgery

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was performed using a computer-generated sequence, with allocation concealment via sealed envelopes

Blinding.evidence: Blinding was not applicable due to the nature of the intervention

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 3,804 patients were randomised: 519 to small, 2,685 to medium, and 600 to large aneurysm groups

Result_Outcome.evidence: Peri-operative mortality was 1.0% for small, 2.3% for medium, and 4.0% for large aneurysms (p = .004). Large aneurysms were associated with increased 30-day mortality (OR 3.3, 95% CI 1.3 – 10.1) and long-term mortality (HR 2.4, 95% CI 1.6 – 3.7)

Harms.evidence: Adverse events included stroke and prolonged length of stay, with higher rates in the large aneurysm group
